comments.commentBody:
The time to cut spending is during a strong economic period, not during a weak one.

Not sure how you define Germany's economy as the "strongest" - largest and most important, perhaps, but several others have higher per capita gdp, including Ireland in 2011.

Japan's problem was a larger version of our current problem - not addressing a financial crisis, a balance sheet recession as aggressively as needed. After years of dithering, the government finally went into the banks and sorted things out while the banks kicked and screamed. But, the damage had already been done to people's confidence, likelihood to consume and take chances, things that are necessary for recovery.
And what would be the purpose of a citizen militia, unless you're planning to go to war against your own government?  The rest of us find the police quite adequate, in fact we insist on it.

The reason for not infringing on "the right of the people to keep and bear arms" is the necessity of "a well regulated militia" -- according to the 2nd Amendment. So doesn't it make sense to execute reasoned, careful background checks (as well as to provide supervised training) for the potential members of such a citizen militia?

I hope that you and the many people who agree with you do not use this sort of frustration, which is is completely justified, as a reason to disengage from the political process. The Daily Show is very amusing, but there is some evidence that overexposure to this brand of political satire increases cynicism, lowers trust in political and media institutions, and--this is the damaging part--reduces feelings that anything can be done to change social ills. So, while the Daily show is funny, the sense of futility in the face of a broken process that people increasingly feel is pretty depressing, because it just makes the process more broken.

Keep your heads up!
Well said.

Rupert Murdoch started his propaganda machine with Fox News and many papers. Now the Koch brothers, oil tycoons, are trying to buy the LA Times to be used as a propaganda outlet against Climate Change. We fail to see the immense power of propaganda to keep the populace like cattle. Those who expose the lies, like Bradley Manning and other Whistle-blowers  are hunted down and silenced. The Media presents madness as "fair and balanced" reporting, giving the likes of Wayne LaPierre a stump to stand on. There is no real source for credible information except for internet site like truthout.org. The rest of the Media has let us down.

"LaPierre’s job is to frighten people; more than a clown, he is the Kim Jong-un of American politics..."  Jon Stewart could not have said it better.  No matter what legislation comes from the dysfunction that is Congress, it will be so watered-down and lacking in utility that it should make every citizen ashamed to live in such a place.  Whether it is gun legislation, health care programs or the size of a soft drink, the process is so stunted that what comes out fixes not a thing.  It is a curse to be a rational observer on the receiving end of nothing but detritus.  Culturally, our country is in a state of undeclared civil war.  Couple that with the abomination of money controlling the political process and laughing at all us suckers out here playing by the rules, and we are in a toxic stew that will do us in.  There have been other times where the Republic was threatened and somehow survived, but when we have access to so much credible information to use in the decision-making process and our legislators not only ignore it, but trample it, it won't be long until we just have to turn out the lights and shut the door.

Things are much simpler. At times when economy is offering few opportunities to make profit, investors turn to gold. Is this political? Yes, as much as 2+2=4. The previous administration arrogantly spend our money on wars; the current administration aspires more than others to mingle with economy. In such environment investing in economy’s growth is more risky than buying gold.

This is something that has been coming to big-time US sports for a long time. Looks like it's just about here. It will drive a very big nail into the coffin of intolerance, right where intolerance is really strong, the NFL/NHL fan base. Should be some interesting reactions.

Keep in mind that this is not really so new -- five or six NFL players have come out or been outed already, though none while still playing. Probably hundreds of athletes in other sports/countries have come out. The Wikipedia page cited in an earlier comment is illuminating.

Beowulf, that oldest of Germanic epics, might have clarified the issue long ago:  gold is of value only when people trust the political and social order.  When the king is weak, gold is worthless (and the dragon hoards it).  That is, gold is just another form of money, and its value floats with levels of public confidence.

The goldbuggers do see runaway inflation: the government lies! the price of milk is up 500% in the last week!, Shadowstats!, etc. etc.

I wish the gold-lovers of the world could see a the absolutely horrific environmental disaster that is modern gold mining.

On the other hand, they're (almost) all political conservatives, so they'd probably be overjoyed to see an industrial operation tearing down a mountain, soaking it in cyanide, and dumping the tailings into a lake that will remain toxic until the end of time.

So right!! We are considering gun control efforts, support for marriage equality is growing by leaps and bounds, we might stop treating immigrants that don't have milky white skin like ax murderers! I'd say we are making strides in societal ways, we are integrating!! Like watching the crowd at a big airport, or at the convention in Charlotte we have a rich make-up of wonderfully diverse people that are prettier than any quilt ever made!!

Gun control isn't going to keep our currency from becoming wallpaper in a decade or two. Controlling spending and borrowing might, if it isn't years too late already.
What should we do, cut back to keep entitlements going, or just bump it all up until dollar-holders and our debtors pull the plug and the dance music stops?
Steve, for economic advice, read Krugman.

I just don't see American society unraveling, nor do I see cataclysmic debt as much of a problem. First, our society is becoming more connected than ever before. We just don't turn our backs on our Facebook friends, or google+ buddies. We LIKE them or give them encouraging replies. It's that simple.

Second, the national debt is not an unsolvable problem. After all we are Americans and we do capitalism very well. We've just got to start nation building in places that need it, like here in America.

Budgets really aren't news worthy. The fact that both political parties are actually talking like real people about gun control and equality is.

Create a Mean And Depraved Society?

For the American Working Class, Inner Cities and Suburban Fringe, (cf, Newark) we already are one.
Yes, when there is a "surplus of workers" the price will drop.  Nice. Any chance that the "savings" will go to those at the top? Naahh...couldn't ever imagine that.

The term "will create" was a bad choice. I did not intend to ignore the large number of people who are having a very rough time in finding a good paying job.

It is frustrating to say the least to listen to the endless talk about the deficit and not very much talk about our real problem of un and underemployed people. Most frustrating is the failure of our business and government leadership to recognize that the best thing we could do, now, is work on putting people back to work in good paying jobs. It is depressing to learn that we have people working in 40 hour jobs at wages so low that they must apply for food stamps.

The sequester was irrational and restoring the payroll tax cut for working people was equally a bad policy action. I know there is plenty of work to be done that would benefit our society and our economy.

We just need to make our mind up that we will do the work and see what life would be like at full employment.

I think Ben Bernanke has his eye on the priority but the WH and the Congress has not come around to understanding the social and economic needs of the American people. We don't have to have a "Nanny State" but we can define the requirements for economically beneficial public investments.

I think the President's budget is a tremendous victory for Mr. Pete Peterson and his paid followers. Very few could take him on. The heroic efforts of Paul Krugman, Robert Reich, Joe Stiglitz and Alan Blinder will be noted in U.S. economic history but their counsel will be a footnote to the collapse of the American economy as it slips into a recession within the Great Recession, and will create a mean and depraved society.

The good news is in about 40 years the aging boomers will have died off and there will be a surplus of healthcare providers and the price of healthcare will drop. The industry will be screaming for patients and there will be a new American renaissance of liberalism and community effort.

.

Lasz, I agree that Patrick B's crossing of ART and CARNEY was inspired, and thus, a SEWER thing!
Surely, 'Twas a fair and lively Friday offering from one of our favorite constructors,, however, at what LACOSTE?

Howie

And the winner is... [drum roll] ... AL ROKER!

ART crossing CARNEY: a stroke of genius. Only 25 blocks and 66 entries: a real pleasure. I needed wraparound sunglasses to stare at this grid.

However, a higher number of proper names put a damper on my enthusiasm to fully endorse this one. I counted 15 names excluding CAESAR -- more than expected from Patrick Berry -- plus many more not clued as proper names: Georg J. LUGER, Stan LAUREL, Norman MAILER, BOGEY, drugstore chain founder Jack ECKERD, PAM Grier. LACOSTA, SPINAR? LACOSTE, SPINER? I took a wild guess at E. Now I am ashamed, since I do own a sweater with the green crocodile logo. I know WES Montgomery and Craven, but not Anderson.

I still enjoyed the themeless challenge, even if a little easier than the average Friday, but am looking forward to Saturday's Barry Silk or Joe Krozel-type challenge.

I'll leave you with the hauntingly beautiful "The LARK Ascending" by Ralph Vaughan Williams:

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZR2JlDnT2l8

Happy Friday all!
If they don't fear us, why do they lie about us and work to deny us equal treatment before the law?

The word "homophobia" is such a misnomer.  A phobia is a fear of something.  The word truly demeans the nature of the issue.  I don't believe those who take a different stance are in fear.  I wish we could all separate true hatred from true differences of opinion.

I applaud the NHL for taking the lead in the You Can Play campaign. There are many hockey players with whom I have been friends for several decades. Not once have I heard a homophobic comment from any of them, but that doesn't mean that there aren't problems in all sports leagues. In am proud that a scout from the Flyers (my home team) has created this initiative.

I suspect they won't miss your revenue all that much, people with any kind of real income generally aren't homophobes, not surprising, given that the religious bigots who are so homophobic are likely to be in the lower tier economically, in large part because of lack of recognition.

It is estimated that about 9 peecent of men and 6 percent of women are homosexuals.

The NFL is a very self-selecting occupation, so it's probably not accurate to assume the NFL is going to accurately reflect the general population.

The Redskins [and all NFL teams] have had gay players and Vince Lombardi's brother was gay, so he made it clear that gay slurs were not acceptable when he was in the room.
Three percent of the population is gay so with 1,700 NFL players that amounts to about 50 players. There are and always be gays players in the NFL.

Annabelle, interestingly enough, religion is also a very popular psychological disorder, and it often goes hand-in-hand with homophobia all 'in the name of God'.

But science shows that homosexuality is naturally occurring in many species, whereas homophobia and religion are both learned human behaviors and nothing to do with nature aside from the fact that some people prefer the supernatural to the natural and imagination to facts.

It will be a big yawn a few years from now and all the rest of what you suggest will be the case then too.  Right now it would be a really big deal.  Obviously you are not gay.  Talking with my sister recently I was surprised what a big deal it is to her when a woman breaks another barrier.  My sister is a very successful professional who owns her own business.  Women are half the population of the world and are heads-of-state and occupy every imaginable position.  In terms of acceptance, LGBT people are way behind.  Yes, it will be a huge deal and the sound of that barrier's falling will thrill me to death.

"leagues have begun exploring ways to accommodate and respond to such a landmark announcement."

The response should be a yawn and advice that the athlete in question please get on with their job, best wishes for good luck, and a firm admonition that their sexuality is as profoundly irrelevant to their profession as to any other. The athlete will be a person and should be treated exactly the same as other people. And I will bet they ask for nothing else.

How about if the NHL announces their support for the players that have been sexually abused by their coaches?  You know, the pedophiles?!  That would make more sense since there are more predators than homosexuals.  It's more important that the abusers are profiled rather than those that have a different sexual interest.

I'm actually replying to Annabelle (she is 8 below jehdc) who seems to think that the American Psychological Association still considers "homosexuality" a mental disorder. I'm pasting in the the question and the first two sentences of the response and then the link to their Web page so you can check it out yourself in case you think I'm making it up or altered it in some way.

"Is homosexuality a mental disorder?

No, lesbian, gay, and bisexual orientations are not disorders. Research has found no inherent association between any of these sexual orientations and psychopathology."

Here is a link to their Web page with the full paragraph

http://www.apa.org/helpcenter/sexual-orientation.aspx

their other diversion game is to talk about the problems with the economy and often blame Obama.

Wasnt the economy in decent shape when clinton left office adn under bush jr it became almost the second great repub depression

Why would the presence of openly gay athletes prevent "sports from being sports"?  Only someone who has no concept of what it's like to be pressured to stay in the closet could reduce this issue to a "political agenda."  When all athletes can be comfortable in their own skin, and not feel the need to hide a major part of their identity, THEN sports will finally "be sports," and only then will the focus be on athletic ability alone.

@ Juan:  free ideas, free speech is not the same as saying that all ideas and all speech are created equal.  In reality, many ideas are intellectually and/or morally bankrupt.   These flaws should be pointed out, not elevated under the banner of false equivalency.  Anti-gay bigotry is not deserving of anything but criticism.  There's no empirical or moral basis for such intolerant views.

"Mr. Davis acknowledged that because many N.F.L. players are deeply religious, open conversations about how their religious beliefs impact their feelings about gay players are necessary."

I think Mr. Davis' comment about the possible obstacle being the players' deep religious convictions is nonsense. If the players were so deeply religious, then why is all the drinking, drug use and sexual playing around by many teamates tolerated?

Answer: nothing. But clearly gay athletes don't feel comfortable casually disclosing their private life in public, the way the 95% (or 99% or whatever) of athletes who are straight do. Why do you think that is?

Heterosexual athletes disclose their private life every time they bring a girlfriend/wife/groupie to the locker room or to a press conference,

Annabelle, above, is deluded when she claims that "Homosexuality is still considered a mental disorder by the American Psychological Association."

What is it about truth and reality that you rightwingers don't understand? Its as if you think that just making claim somehow makes your disingenuous comments true.

Here is what the APA has to say about homosexuality on its website:

Lesbian, gay, and bisexual orientations are not disorders. Research has found no inherent association between any of these sexual orientations and psychopathology. Both heterosexual behavior and homosexual behavior are normal aspects of human sexuality. Both have been documented in many different cultures and historical eras. Despite the persistence of stereotypes that portray lesbian, gay, and bisexual people as disturbed, several decades of research and clinical experience have led all mainstream medical and mental health organizations in this country to conclude that these orientations represent normal forms of human experience. Lesbian, gay, and bisexual relationships are normal forms of human bonding. Therefore, these mainstream organizations long ago abandoned classifications of homosexuality as a mental disorder.

I agree about the point regarding Reus and Ozil - both have been exceptional for Germany - but I still stand by the point that Schweinsteiger, with whichever yard stick you chose to condemn him with, has been a different player for Germany than he has been for Bayern.

In this exercise I chose goals scored, but the general point about his performances is undeniable.
